[Section: Page 469 of 1048]



Message 1795 of 4024
Robert, I don’t have the same luxury of time to pull together emails such as below.
Then the expectation  is I read every word, pull out something for a response that is embedded with.
You send me multiple emails and expect a back and forth. I can’t do that.
My days are one work, errand to another. I know that bothers you.
Your excuse for not having a job is that it will require you to put a full days work in and can’t devote to nothing else. That is the reality that majority
of humans deal with.
I don’t see any outstanding issues at this time that need me to be in this platform for the next few hours, so yes I am going to pivot to chores I can’t get
done during a working week PLUS work.
Sent:03/02/2024 at 09:29 AM
From:Christine Moyer
To:Robert Moyer (First Viewed: 03/02/2024 at 10:05 AM)
Subject:Re: Are you done?
Message 1796 of 4024
Thanks!
That is not my expectation. My expectation is that if we are solving an issue, we either do that or you let me know you are stepping away. Just
curiosity.
-  I assume we kill the basketball idea I had for AD
- I hoped to reach an agreement on Sonos for today
I don’t know either. They both seem to need an answer so I can plan.
The suggestions for Dr Brown improving us can wait but are important.
About the whole job thing, I know you mentioned that a lot, and don’t understand why I don’t do the same thing you do.
I think the easiest explanation is a simple recognition of what is going on. I had my whole life turned upside down on July 5. I found out you were
fooling around with a married man who works for you. I soon had my kids taken, my house taken, and then a restraining orders put on me that say I
beat you and my kids.
So think of it this way. You launched an unexpected attack on a neighboring country-me. You bomb me day and night. I thought we were at peace,
allies. We are not now in a covert move. So you go about your business. Your attack was planned. I alternatively am fighting for my life to understand
what my future is.
It’s a pretty accurate metaphor. Does that help?

From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 03/02/2024 at 10:41 AM)
Subject:Re: Are you done?

I asked you about basketball and what was next. You did not answer.
Sonos I told you I would look.
I held a job down that you actively tried to destroy for years.

Sent:03/02/2024 at 01:35 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 03/02/2024 at 01:46 PM)
Subject:Improving our Relationship for Everyone

When you said “no” I walked away. It was not the outcome I wanted, but you refused and what is more important is that you see I respect your
wishes.
Please note that just because we argue about “if we should ride a roller coaster” it in no way reflects if we will actually enjoy the ride. It’s the same
thing here.
OFW and no attempts at civility got us here. You know that. Please try something new for a change. I’m not asking you to reaffirm your vows.
If we are not nice, or if it goes sideways, we stop that moment. End of story. There is no long term commitment involved. It’s juts trying something
new.
This is a very painless way to see if it allows us to be more civil on other platforms. If we are kind in person, it may help us extend that civility to OFW
too.
- What we’re doing doesn’t work.
- I walked away when you said no.
- I will also, if needed during “our try.”
- It really can’t hurt us just to try
- You can choose what we do to try
Please consider. It costs us nothing and the potential upside is enormous.
Thanks!
Message 1802 of 4024
I noticed my reaction.
I’m clearly in a space where being pushed is a trigger for me.
I am trying.

Hope you have a wonderful night.

-robert

You just learn how to do it (it’s like the show we used to watch at Alki) and make some goofy craft (not like the show we watched at Alki... )
If you would allow, we could just meet there and take the class. We hardly even need to talk. And it might be fun given how competitive we are with

Sent:03/03/2024 at 06:04 AM
From:Christine Moyer
To:Robert Moyer (First Viewed: 03/03/2024 at 08:17 AM)
Subject:Re: Improving our Relationship for Everyone
Message 1810 of 4024
I appreciate your thoughtful consideration of my suggestion. I recognize and respect your need for time and space to heal as we navigate the
complexities of our current situation. The point I would like to make thoughtfully and constructively again is that the "time to heal" path is the one
we have taken since this began. So, reflecting on the results of that path, I am discouraged. I would propose balancing the "time to heal" with an
option that at least changes up the recipe that has only made things worse by engaging in a neutral activity, which could serve as a meaningful step
towards this goal.
I want to remove the tensions that mark our interactions by providing a space where we can be in the same room and enjoy a shared moment someone
else is directing. It is not about forgetting the challenges we face or disagreements that remain; it's about creating a moment that reminds us of the
fundamental respect and connection that sustained us in better times. I hope the new ingredient in our recipe helps us respect our shared history and
our love for our kids so we can establish a more congenial relationship that allows us to make decisions with less emotion and in their best interest.
I understand this is a small step in a much larger journey of healing and reconciliation, and it doesn’t pretend to be a cure-all for the challenges we
face. But given that what we are doing today is not working, I believe it's worth taking if it can lead us towards a more respectful and understanding
relationship, acknowledging our shared history and our love for our family. As mentioned, I'm open to this or any other activity that feels right to
you, and I'm committed to listening to your thoughts and suggestions. I'll wait, but let's find a way to move forward that honors our children and our
individual paths to healing.
I know this scares you. I know you have concerns. But I assure you it is not meant to replace your healing process, which I fully respect and support. It
is to complement it. What we are doing is not working, so I'm grateful for your willingness to consider this on our journey toward becoming effective
co-parents. And we can always just walk away if we don't enjoy it. Let's blow some glass!
Have a great day....
Sent:03/03/2024 at 11:12 AM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 03/03/2024 at 11:26 AM)
Subject:Re: Improving our Relationship for Everyone

Message 1819 of 4024
Good Morning,
In the quiet moments following this weekend's tensions, I've found myself deeply reflecting on us—not just in the context of our family, but as two
individuals who've shared a life together. This period of separation has prompted me to appreciate the magnitude of what we've achieved over the
years. Despite our differences, perhaps even our incompatibilities, we've built something truly significant, and it shows in our kids. It's a testament to
our efforts, my deep respect for you, and what we've tried to accomplish together.
Perhaps later than you, I realize that we are far more different as human beings than I knew before- on so many levels. I believe neither of us was ready
for what we dove headlong into on "Ashbury beach picture day" with a belief we could will our way through, with best intentions, ignoring our own
baggage from our pasts. Our commitment to making marriage work was remarkable in itself. Whether driven by love, duty, or the sheer desire to
uphold our vows, what we did was real, challenging, and worthy of recognition.
I don't want another long message, instead, I'll simply express my hope for a future where we can sit down together, acknowledging the good times
and the tough, with a focus on moving forward. In a future where we appreciate our efforts without judgment, we understand that we may not have
been fully prepared for the challenges we faced, but we recognize the sincerity of our attempts. I'll be the first to admit that I wish I had the wisdom
you have now, back then, and made an effort to change sooner. Hindsight is 20/20.
I acknowledge your efforts are coming from a place you believe is best. But I hope you will open up to a shared perspective from someone who has
lessons of his own from the past he wants to share from also.
I'm here if you need anything. And I mean that. Have a great day.
-robert

Message 1851 of 4024
I hope you can take a moment and approve this again. If we are intellectually honest with each other, we are doing things to get things done already;
I'm just in danger.
1-1 FYI, emails with inline comments seem like a no-brainer. We have AD basketball camp, SAAS state tournament, and Mark's AMEX that all fit
that bill recently.
Plain 1-1 emails with you where we drop a 3rd party seem incredibly useful but are not allowed either. We really needed that yesterday to act on SAAS
quickly.
Emergency OFW calls are a no-brainer. SAAS was urgent enough for you to reach out to me immediately. I need the same option if you are just not
available.

Message 1882 of 4024
I see the call is at 3:15. I will update our Teams meeting accordingly and see you at 3:00.
I also want to continue our working relationship the way we have done the last couple of days and correct what just happened. So I will propose the
following guidelines designed to help us be more respectful so we can have a constructive dialogue that limits triggering each other. And if it happens
anyway, despite this, I am proposing we note that and ask for a resolution of either stopping the conversation or giving the other a chance to correct
or reconcile the triggering action. We need to afford each other the opportunity to course correct a mistake.
Please consider these suggestions.
- Respectful Tone: Speak as if to your boss, respectfully and thoughtfully as if you might get fired.
- No Recap's: Allow each person to express their thoughts without interruption or a "playback."
- No Abrupt Endings: Don't end conversations suddenly after disagreements. Ask for an apology first.
- Listen Actively: Show you're listening without interrupting, using nods or brief acknowledgments.
- Use "I" Statements: Say "I feel..." instead of "you make me..." to express personal feelings without blame.
- Pause Before Responding: Take a moment to think before replying to provide more thoughtful responses.
- Avoid Assumptions: Don't assume intentions or feelings; ask for clarification and limit predetermination.
- Stay on Topic: Focus on the current issue without bringing up unrelated past grievances. Note if it happens.
- Respect Boundaries: If someone needs a break, respect it. Agree on when to continue the conversation.
- Use Neutral Language: Be factual and use non-inflammatory words to keep the discussion productive.
Do you agree? Can we do this in a calm way and ask each other to follow these together?
